introPages.title: What are determiners?
introPages.body:
Determiners go before a noun. They tell us which thing(s), whose, how many, or how much.

In Part 2, the gap is often before a noun and needs an article (a, an, the), a quantifier (some, many, both), a possessive (its, their), or a demonstrative (this, that).

introPages.title: Articles: a, an, the
introPages.body:
A and an – for one thing in general, when you first mention it: I saw ___ cat. → a

The – when we know which one, or when we refer back: I saw ___ cat again. → the

Use an before a vowel sound: an hour, an idea.

introPages.title: Quantifiers
introPages.body:
Some in positive statements; any in questions and negatives (usually).

Much + uncountable noun (much time); many + countable plural (many reasons).

Both + plural; each/every + singular. All can go with plural or uncountable.

Examples: both sides, each day, every student, no time.

introPages.title: Possessives and demonstratives
introPages.body:
Possessives: my, your, his, her, its, our, their. They show who owns or has the noun.

Its = belonging to it (no apostrophe). It's = it is.

Demonstratives: this/that + singular; these/those + plural.

introPages.title: Rules for gaps
introPages.body:
• Look at the noun after the gap – is it singular or plural? Countable or uncountable?
  • First mention? → a/an. Refer back or specific? → the.
  • Some vs any: positive = some; question/negative = any (usually).
  • Both, each, every: check if the noun is singular or plural.

mcQuiz.question: What do determiners do?
options: They go before a noun and specify which/whose/how many
mcQuiz.explanation: Determiners go before a noun and specify which thing(s), whose, or how many/much.

mcQuiz.question: In I saw ___ cat (first mention), which article fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: On first mention of a singular countable noun, we use a or an.

mcQuiz.question: When do we use the?
options: When we know which one or refer back
mcQuiz.explanation: We use 'the' when we refer back or when it's clear which one we mean.

mcQuiz.question: Some is usually used in which type of sentence?
mcQuiz.explanation: Some is usually used in positive statements. Any is typical in questions and negatives.

mcQuiz.question: What is the rule for much vs many?
mcQuiz.explanation: Much goes with uncountable nouns (much time); many with countable plurals (many reasons).

mcQuiz.question: Does both go with a singular or plural noun?
mcQuiz.explanation: Both means 'the two', so it takes a plural noun (both sides, both students).

mcQuiz.question: What is the difference between its and it's?
options: its = belonging to it; it's = it is
it's = belonging to it; its = it is
mcQuiz.explanation: Its = belonging to it (no apostrophe). It's = it is. A common mistake is using it's when its is meant.

shortQuestions.question: Where do determiners go in relation to the noun?
shortQuestions.explanation: Determiners always go before the noun they specify.

shortQuestions.question: Which article do you use when you first mention something?
shortQuestions.explanation: Use a or an for the first mention of a singular countable noun.

shortQuestions.question: Which article do you use when you refer back to something already mentioned?
shortQuestions.explanation: Use 'the' when referring back or when it's clear which one.

shortQuestions.question: In positive statements, do we usually use some or any?
shortQuestions.explanation: Some is typical in positive statements; any in questions and negatives.

shortQuestions.question: Does much go with countable or uncountable nouns?
shortQuestions.explanation: Much goes with uncountable nouns (much time, much water). Many goes with countable plurals.

shortQuestions.question: Does both take a singular or plural noun?
shortQuestions.explanation: Both means 'the two', so it takes a plural noun.

shortQuestions.question: Which word means 'belonging to it' – its or it's?
shortQuestions.explanation: Its = belonging to it (no apostrophe). It's = it is.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why is it important to look at the noun after the gap when choosing a determiner?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: The noun tells you if you need singular (a, the, this) or plural (these, those, both, many). It also tells you if the noun is countable (many, few) or uncountable (much, little).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give two examples of sentences where a or an fits the gap.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. I saw ___ cat. / She had ___ idea. The gap is before a singular countable noun on first mention.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When might you use the instead of a?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: When you refer back to something already mentioned, when it's clear which one (the sun, the government), or when the noun is unique or specific in context.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the difference between some and any.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Some: usually in positive statements (I have some time). Any: in questions (Do you have any?) and negatives (I don't have any). Exceptions exist (Would you like some? – offers).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why does both take a plural noun?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Both means 'the two' – it refers to two things, so the noun must be plural: both sides, both students, both ideas.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is a common mistake with its and it's?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: People often write it's (it is) when they mean its (belonging to it). Its has no apostrophe. It's = it is.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: How do you choose between this/that and these/those?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: This/that + singular (this book, that idea). These/those + plural (these books, those ideas). Look at the noun after the gap.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three quantifiers that go with uncountable nouns.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. much, little, some, any, a lot of, no.
